clinical_study.brief_title: Characterization of an Optically Pumped Magnetometer (OPM) Magnetoencephalography (MEG) Array
clinical_study.official_title: Characterization of an Optically Pumped Magnetometer (OPM) Magnetoencephalography (MEG) Array
clinical_study.source: National Institutes of Health Clinical Center (CC)

brief_summary.textblock:
Background:
Brain activity produces magnetic fields. These fields can be measured outside the head. Existing technology, called MEG, measures these fields. Researchers are testing a new type of magnetic field sensor called OPM. They hope it can help pinpoint with very high accuracy where brain activity is generated.
Objective:
To develop and test a new type of sensor for measuring the magnetic fields produced by brain activity.
Eligibility:
Healthy people ages 18-65 who had a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan under protocol 17-M-0181.
Design:
Participants may be asked to complete sessions on both the traditional MEG instrument and the OPM array.
For the MEG, 3 small coils will be placed on the participant s face with tape. Their head will be positioned inside the MEG device.
For the OPM, sensors are housed in a 3d printed array. The sensors will be attached to a cap placed on the participant s head.
For both scans, participants will be seated in a chair inside a magnetically shielded room. They may complete several tasks. In one task, plastic cells will be placed on their fingers. Puffs of air will be sent to these cells, which will stimulate the sense of touch. Other tasks may include the following stimuli: visual (such as checkerboards), auditory (such as beeps and tones), or language (words and letters).
Researchers may also obtain recordings while they stimulate the nerve in the participant s forearm using electrical current in small electrodes.
Participation is expected to last for 1 day. Additional optional scans may be offered for up to 1 year....

detailed_description.textblock:
Currently available functional neuroimaging techniques can meet many, but not all needs of clinical neuroscientists. While functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is able to map brain function to millimeter resolution, it has poor temporal resolution. In contrast, magnetoencephalography (MEG) directly measures magnetic fields generated by populations of neurons. The factors limiting the spatial resolution of MEG include the finite number of sensors compared to brain sources, and the available signal to noise ratio (SNR). Whole head SQUID based MEG systems have been employed to study a wide array of brain processes and pathologies, including aging, neurodegeneration, memory, semantic processing, and network organization. The signals measured using MEG consist primarily of summed postsynaptic potentials generated by populations of pyramidal cells firing in synchrony. The signals measured by MEG may represent either a field time-locked to a stimulus, or populations of neurons oscillating in synchrony. Important gains in neuroscience have been made with MEG, despite the current limitations of the technology. Development of a non-invasive MEG technology capable of resolution approaching that ECoG could open entirely new domains of noninvasive human neuroscience. This protocol is a technical development protocol to characterize an optically pumped magnetometer (OPM) array used for measuring magnetic brain signals. Our OPM array can be placed directly on the surface of the scalp, dramatically improving SNR.
The Final OPM array will have 49-61 primary sensors, although we may assemble an interim array with fewer sensors. We will fully characterize the performance of the array all stages, and we will also validate the array using somatotopic mapping of the receptive fields of each finger, and potentially each phalanx of each finger. This protocol will recruit up to 75 healthy male and female participants aged 18-65, from the greater Washington DC metropolitan area. Participants will receive MEG recordings on a traditional MEG system and/or our experimental OPM system.

primary_outcome.description: At each phase of array construction characterization parameters including signal to noise, sensitivity, bandwidth, and spatial resolution will be measured.

secondary_outcome.description: Somatotopic representations of the digits of the hand, potentially differentiating the individual phalanx of each finger.

arm_group.description: Testing of a final 49-61 channel OPM MEG system and any interim arrays

intervention.description: MEG recordings acquired on a standard whole brain SQUID MEG system. Stimuli will be used, including auditory, visual, or somatosensory stimuli. Language stimuli and median nerve stimulation may also be used.

MEG recordings acquired on an investigational OPM MEG system. Stimuli will be used, including auditory, visual, or somatosensory stimuli. Language stimuli and median nerve stimulation may also be used.

criteria.textblock:
- INCLUSION CRITERIA:
In order to be eligible to participate in this study, an individual must meet all of the following criteria:
1. Provision of signed and dated informed consent form
2. Stated willingness to comply with all study procedures and availability for the duration of the study
3. Male or female, aged 18-65
4. In good general health as evaluated according to protocol 17-M-0181
5. Completed a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan under 17-M-0181
EXCLUSION CRITERIA:
An individual who meets any of the following criteria will be excluded from participation in this study:
1. Participants excluded from 17-M-0181 will be excluded from this protocol
2. Metal in the body which would cause artifacts on MEG recordings
